text: but I'd like to go back to the stage
whoever's in charge this is actually my
first time at a young adult cancer
conference and I remember during the
opening ceremony looking around me and
realizing that there are 450 other
people just like me we've gone through
these terrible things it was really
emotional
I think after struggling for so long to
find a community it felt so meaningful
and so powerful so much has happened
both good and bad in this past year I've
lost some very good friends too I am
aware that cancer isn't fair but I think
the most important thing is not to focus
on that interruption but to really
figure out how we can make the most of
those Life interrupted moments so that
we can take the time that we have and
move forward and look forward
my name is Julia July and I read The
Life interrupted home and the New York
Times very chronicle of my experience as
a twenty-something with cancer cancer is
not something that makes you want to
share something that makes you want to
hide
especially when you're 22 and you're the
only person that you know has had to
deal with the life-threatening illness
and they're concentrated focus on a lot
of other issues like sexual health
fertility relationships writing for me
has really been the best therapy that I
could possibly imagine to take control
of this really unfortunate thing that's
happened in my life and to turn it into
a positive
this is the first time that I've met a
lot of the people who read my work who
write to me my chat with on Twitter and
it's been so amazing to see these people
in person I almost feel like I already
know them even never just meeting for
the first time there are days when I
feel overexposed and there are days when
I worry that I've become the cancer girl
I guess I never realized how much
responsibility becomes the territory of
sharing your story so publicly I've had
to learn what topics I'm comfortable
speaking about in which I'd rather just
keep for myself
I'm here in Vegas with four beautiful
young women with cancer who have also
become my best best friend and really
surreal because I've met all of them
through the internet when you're a
patient who's feeling isolated or who's
not able to get out of bed there's this
entire community at your fingertips this
is so nice to have a close-knit group of
girlfriends were there for you through
the good and the bad without worrying
that you're going to be the buzzkill
because you're the girl who's sick it's
crazy for me to think that just one year
ago and this in a bone marrow transplant
unit and I
and it didn't know if I was going to
survive that summer I think the biggest
thing that makes that so special is that
I'm well enough to do these things which
is not always be given
I'm still doing one week of treatment
every month and that can be really
difficult
before that health is always my priority
and I've had to learn to balance this
work that I care so much about in a way
that doesn't take away from my recovery
I know that I'm able to handle the
things that are in my way and there was
a strength that comes with knowing that
and I don't feel as scared as I used to
when I think about the future
